title: EU Preps US Counter Measures, Safe Havens Rise, Swedish Fighter Jets | Bloomberg Daybreak:...

rawLines.text: [Music]
Bloomberg Audio Studios podcasts, radio,
news.
This is the Bloomberg Daybreet podcast.
Good morning. It's Monday the 14th of
July. I'm Caroline Hepka in London
and I'm Steven Carol in Brussels. Coming
up today, the EU lines up allies and
counter measures as Trump threatens a
30% tariff from the 1st of August if no
agreement can be reached.
Help wanted but not by humans. UK hiring
tumbles as AI disrupts jobs and payroll
costs surge in another worrying sign for
Star and Reeves.
Plus, why Europe's defense ramp up is
creating an opportunity for Sweden's
Griffin fighter jet to take off.
Let's start with a roundup of our top
stories.
The European Union is looking to step up
engagement with other countries hit by
Trump's tariffs following a slew of new
threats. Sources tell us that the EU has
reached out to nations including Canada
and Japan and raised the prospect of a
coordinated response to US levies. The
move comes after President Trump
unleashed his latest tariff ultimatum
over the weekend. The US President
declared that the EU and Mexico would
face a 30% tariff if agreements can't be
reached by the 1st of August. European
Commission President Ursa Vanderline
says she's hopeful of a deal.
We prefer a negotiated solution. This
remains the case and we will use the
time that we have now till the 1st of
August.
Ursa Vanderline says the European Union
will extend the suspension of trade
counter measures against the US until
the start of next month in a bid to
secure a deal. At the same time,
Germany's Chancellor Friedrich Mertz
said 30% tariffs would hit exporters in
Europe's largest economies to the core
if a negotiated solution in the trade
conflict can't be found.
China's export growth has accelerated
for the first time since March. Exports
rose year by a higher than expected 5.8%
in June to $325 billion. Bloomberg's
Minman Low says the pickup was driven by
a reduction in US tariffs and robust
demand from key overseas markets.
The exports are really bolstered by the
trade crews, the front loing of
shipments. Economists have been telling
us that we really have to prepare for a
potential, you know, fall off in demand
for exports in the second half of the
year. And of course, we are still
waiting for the mid- August deadline
when the temporary truce will expire.
And some economists believe it's still a
possibility that maybe the tariff levels
could still increase in the later half
of this year. So there's still a lot of
uncertainty there.
Min low speaking there. The US tariffs
on Chinese goods have been cut back to
around 55% down from as high as 145% in
early April. However, Beijing faces
mounting risks from Washington's
evolving trade strategy. Treasury
Secretary Scott Bessent is expected to
meet his Chinese counterpart in the
coming weeks.
Bloomberg understands that Jane Street
has deposited over 48 billion rupees,
the equivalent of $564 million in an
escrow account to comply with an order
from India's market regulator. It comes
after the Securities and Exchange Board
of India temporarily banned the trading
giant from accessing the local market
over allegations of index manipulation.
The deposit enables Jain Street to
resume trading in India, but sources say
the firm does not intend to return to
trading in local equity options. While
Jane Street has not commented on the
latest development, it has previously
stated that it strongly rejects the
premise and substance of the regulators
order, calling it fundamentally mistaken
about its trades.
Now, here in the UK, hiring by
businesses is down by the most in nearly
two years, according to data from the
consultancy KPMG and the Recruitment and
Employment Confederation. The numbers
come as employers show signs of dialing
back hiring for jobs likely to be
affected by artificial intelligence.
Bloomberg's Tio Adabio has more. Online
job postings in the UK have dropped 31%
in the three months to May compared to
2022. According to McKenzie analysis,
the decline is being felt most in
sectors with the potential to be
significantly altered by AI, including
areas such as tech and finance. Data
shows job postings for these sorts of
roles dropped almost twice as much as
others. The trend presents another drag
on a job market already contending with
tax increases and stalling economic
growth. In London, Tiwa Adabio,
Bloomberg Radio.
Britain has announced a date for the
state visit from US President Donald
Trump. The country will host the
American leader from the 17th of
September after Prime Minister Kier
Starmer invited Trump for a rare second
visit. Bloomberg's James Wilco has more.
Flashery can get you a long way. In
Britain's case, flattery seems to have
helped K star secure a 20 percentage
point lower tariff rate than that of the
EU, which would be a major coup if it
holds. And global leaders admit to
taking notes from this moment.
Can I present a letter from McCain to
Thank you very much.
Oh, that's well that is really nice.
A very special letter. I think the last
state visit was a tremendous success. It
was
uh His Majesty the king wants to make
this even better. uh than that. So this
is this is truly historic an
unprecedented second visit if he wants
to.
So can Stan perform a second flourish
and lever the UK's pageantry industry
into real gains on trade and security
from the US leader in London. James
Wilco, Bloomberg Radio.
President Donald Trump says that the US
will send more Patriot air defense
batteries to Ukraine as long as Europe
pays. The move is a change of heart for
the US leader, who had argued that
sending more arms would delay any peace
deal. Ukraine had been receiving US
weapons, but only with money remaining
from Joe Biden's time in office.
President Trump says that he won't be
footing the bill for the new deliveries.
I haven't agreed on the number yet, but
they're going to have some because they
do need protection. But the European
Union is paying for it. We're not paying
anything for it, but we will send it.
and it'll be business for us and we will
send them patriots which they
desperately need.
The president added that he is very
disappointed with Russian President
Vladimir Putin. NATO chief Mark Russia
is scheduled to meet with Trump later
today as Axios reports that Trump will
announce a new plan for Ukraine that
also includes offensive weapons.
And in sports news, Yanek has captured
his first Wimbledon title after
defeating the defending champion Carlos
Alcarz in four sets. Speaking after the
match, the Italian world number one
acknowledged the challenges he's faced
this year.
I'm very emotional. No, even if I don't
cry, but it feels uh feels emotional
because only me and and the people who
are close to me know exactly what we
have been through on and off the court.
And it has been everything except easy.
Alex Center, who also served a
three-month doping ban earlier in the
year, speaking there. Elsewhere, Chelsea
claims the Football Club World Cup
title, beating Paris San 3-nil in the
final. The London side were presented
with the trophy by US President Donald
Trump at the Metife Stadium in New
Jersey.
Those are our top stories for you this
morning. Let's have a look at markets
where stock futures are tumbling right
now for Europe. Down by half of 1% for
the US stocks 50 futures. real concerns
around President Trump's tariff threat
of 30% against Europe. S&P 500 even
futures also announcing some declines
down 4/10en this morning. Looking at the
euro marginally lower against the
dollar, down about a tenth of 1% for the
euro 11675. The Mexican peso is also
down 210 against the dollar because it's
another country uh in the sights of
President Trump uh with tariffs. Asian
equities are mixed. You got the topics
up. The Cosby also seeing some gains uh
but we've had some declines for example
for the Taiwanese stock market. Looking
at Treasury yields hovering around 441.
The only other really big notable move
again is in Bitcoin $121,000.
So it's breaking has broken through
another record high for Bitcoin. Those
are the markets. Stephen,
in a moment we'll bring you the latest
on the US EU trade moves. Plus why
Sweden's fighter jet industry could be
poised for takeoff. But another story
we've been reading this morning from our
opinion columnist Howard Chaywan who has
been writing about getting healthy again
while a little bit older at 66. I
decided to get healthy again as the
essay that he's written for Bloomberg's
weekend edition. Um with some
interesting I mean we've we like to
feature how's writing a lot because he
writes beautifully and in a very sort of
relatable way about some of the kind of
challenges he's had like taking up
running uh in his 60s again. He he gave
it up earlier because of an injury as
well. And he's kind of talking about the
the challenges of trying to be as active
as possible. Yes.
While also not compromising entirely on
the things that he enjoys in life like
eating out.
Yeah. Absolutely. He's a Boniv is he
just is uh such a great writer. Also
that he often goes back to you know
ancient texts which I just love. You
know he brings up lots of kind of Roman
writers and he's got all sorts of
interesting quotes that he um includes
and kind of philosophical thinking. It
was based on science because he was
looking at this recent scientific study
that uh anybody who might be a little
bit older um had probably spotted which
is that apparently we age at certain
points. It doesn't sort of happen
gradually but at around the age of 44
and around the age of 60 you can kind of
age quite rapidly. So he was trying to
reverse that time
and just like that effect you know and
just like that you're feeling much older
than perhaps you were last week or the
week before. There's great advice in
there though from Howard too and
essentially I mean a lot of it just
comes down to don't give up and doing a
little is better than doing nothing at
all. Um and you we'll put a link to the
piece in our show notes. It's a great
read this morning.
Now let's bring you more on our top
story. So the EU is preparing to step up
contacts with the likes of Canada and
Japan after Donald Trump threatened to
impose tariffs of 30% on its exports. EU
trade ministers are meeting in Brussels
today to discuss the latest. Our
Brussels bureau chief Suzanne Lynch is
joining us now for more. Suzanne, good
morning. What do we know about the
latest steps that the EU is planning? Is
this about trying to form alliances
against the US?
Well, we reported late last night that
the EU is preparing to step up
engagement with other countries that are
hit by the Trump tariffs. Um mainly it
seems after this week of um and Donald
Trump digging down on his trade
rhetoric, sending those letters to
various trading partners and then at the
weekend announcing or threatening the
European Union and Mexico with with new
tariffs. Um so we know that there is
plan out to coordinate um a lot better
on this. Um but at the same time we've
got the EU at the other hand signaling
quite strongly by Ursula Vanderion on
Sunday that they don't want to escalate
at the moment um and that they're
holding back implementing any more
counter measures until they try and get
some kind of a deal before this new
August 1st deadline.
Suzan, talk us to us about the strategy
that the EU is taking here because the
decision not to retaliate is a choice.
Does it indicate that they are hopeful
that c progress can be made between now
and the 1st of August?
Well, it's um interesting timing because
today, as you mentioned, EU trade
ministers are meeting here in Brussels.
But today is also the deadline by which
a suspended tariffs on steel and
aluminum expire. So the EU has a choice
today as it happens whether to extend
that suspension or to enact that
suspension again and those tariffs
again. So we've heard very strongly from
Vander Lion that at the moment today the
EU won't do that that it will allow that
uh suspension to continue. So it it did
have that option if you like and and
they have chosen not to do that. Um now
what is interesting is that we you know
we're hearing that for example from
President Mron if you look at the
language he used on Saturday when he
responded to this kind of shock move by
Trump he talked about the fact that the
commission have to protect European
interests. He talked about preparing
series of counter measures um including
this trade tool called the anti-coercion
instrument that could you know allow the
EU to hit back even stronger. He
mentioned those things. Now the EU
hasn't gone there yet. Um, as I say, it
is at this moment deciding not to go any
further. But it will be interesting to
see, you know, if there is some push
back now today when EU trade ministers
meeting that some countries perhaps
believe, look, the EU needs to be
stronger on this because, you know, as
we've discussed before, the EU does have
these other measures it can take. It has
other sanctions that it can h implement
h if it chooses to do so.
Okay. Well, let's watch that closely.
Suzanne, thank you so much for being
with us this morning. That is
Bloomberg's Brussels Bureau Chief
Suzanne Lynch.
The move to ramp up defense spending in
Europe is presenting an opportunity for
the Griffin jet made by Sweden's SAB.
The company hasn't secured an export
order since 2014, but that might be
about to change. Our reporter
Christopher Youngstat joins us now for
more from Stockholm. Christopher, good
morning. Is this the moment then for the
Griffin fighter jet?
It sure does look like it's a a moment
definitely. As you mentioned, it's been
over a decade since Saab won a major
export order for its its grip and jets.
But in the past year, both Thailand and
Colombia have decided that they do want
to place orders. And these are now being
negotiated with Saab targeting deals
being finalized this year. And then next
in line could be orders from Peru and
the Philippines uh with Brazil
potentially also boosting its existing
contract for 36 jets by 25%. And as as
Saab CEO Michael Johansson said in his
typical understated fashion, it's been a
while since the company was in such an
intensive period on the gapen front.
Well, Loheed Martin's F-35 fighter jets
of course have dominated order books in
Europe, but here two countries sort of
looking for alternatives,
right? Yeah. 13 European countries are
are current F-35 customers and that's
including Sweden's neighbors Norway,
Denmark and and Finland. While Saab in
its turn has just leased Gripen jets to
the Czech Republic and Hungary. The fact
that Sweden hasn't been a NATO member
has historically been one of their
competitors main arguments for not
buying the Gripen. But with Sweden now a
member, that's of course gone from their
playbooks. What's potentially an even
bigger change, however, is the foreign
policy shift of the Trump
administration. Uh pulling back support,
as we all know, for Ukraine and raising
doubts about US commitment to Europe's
defense, uh which is quite frankly
uncharted territory for European
leaders.
So what's the hope then in terms of new
orders for the Grip and Jet and for SAB
that makes it?
Well, Saab executives have long
emphasized that the procurement of a
fighter jet is as much a political
process as it is a purely technical one.
uh buying weapons and military gear from
the US has long been viewed as a
foolproof method to reach guaranteed
friendship and support. But that is now
of course no longer the case. Uh with
some security analysts believing that
trust in the US will never go back to
pre-Trump levels. Consequently, uh
European countries are now trying to tow
the line between lessening their
dependence on the US and maintaining a
healthy relationship as allies. Uh some
are starting to consider dual fleets
that is mixing Europeanmade fighters
with their F-35s and this to make up for
a potentially lower level of US air
support in the region. And some analysts
expect European countries to spend a far
smaller portion of its defense spending
on US equipment over time as it supplies
more of its own fighter aircraft.
This is Bloomberg Daybreak Europe, your
morning brief on the stories making news
from London to Wall Street and beyond.
Look for us on your podcast feed every
morning on Apple, Spotify, and anywhere
else you get your podcasts.
You can also listen live each morning on
London DAB Radio, the Bloomberg Business
App, and Bloomberg.com.
Our flagship New York station is also
available on your Amazon Alexa devices.
Just say, "Alexa, play Bloomberg 11:30."
I'm Caroline Hepka.
And I'm Steven Carroll. Join us again
tomorrow morning for all the news you
need to start your day right here on
Bloomberg Daybreak Europe.
[Music]

cleanText:
[Music]
Bloomberg Audio Studios podcasts, radio, news.
This is the Bloomberg Daybreak podcast.
Good morning.
It's Monday the 14th of July.
I'm Caroline Hepka in London and I'm Steven Carol in Brussels.
Coming up today, the EU lines up allies and counter measures as Donald Trump threatens a 30% tariff from the 1st of August if no agreement can be reached.
Help wanted but not by humans.
UK hiring tumbles as AI disrupts jobs and payroll costs surge in another worrying sign for Star and Reeves.
Plus, why Europe's defense ramp up is creating an opportunity for Sweden's Griffin fighter jet to take off.
Let's start with a roundup of our top stories.
The European Union is looking to step up engagement with other countries hit by President Donald Trump's tariffs following a slew of new threats.
Sources tell us that the EU has reached out to nations including Canada and Japan and raised the prospect of a coordinated response to US levies.
The move comes after President Donald Trump unleashed his latest tariff ultimatum over the weekend.
The US President declared that the EU and Mexico would face a 30% tariff if agreements can't be reached by the 1st of August.
European Commission President Ursa Vanderline says she's hopeful of a deal.
We prefer a negotiated solution.
This remains the case and we will use the time that we have now till the 1st of August.
Ursa Vanderline says the European Union will extend the suspension of trade counter measures against the US until the start of next month in a bid to secure a deal.
At the same time, Germany's Chancellor Friedrich Mertz said 30% tariffs would hit exporters in Europe's largest economies to the core if a negotiated solution in the trade conflict can't be found.
China's export growth has accelerated for the first time since March.
Exports rose year by a higher than expected 5.8% in June to $325 billion.
Bloomberg's Minman Low says the pickup was driven by a reduction in US tariffs and robust demand from key overseas markets.
The exports are really bolstered by the trade crews, the front loing of shipments.
Economists have been telling us that we really have to prepare for a potential fall off in demand for exports in the second half of the year.
And of course, we are still waiting for the mid- August deadline when the temporary truce will expire.
And some economists believe it's still a possibility that maybe the tariff levels could still increase in the later half of this year.
So there's still a lot of uncertainty there.
Min low speaking there.
The US tariffs on Chinese goods have been cut back to around 55% down from as high as 145% in early April.
However, Beijing faces mounting risks from Washington's evolving trade strategy.
Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent is expected to meet his Chinese counterpart in the coming weeks.
Bloomberg understands that Jane Street has deposited over 48 billion rupees, the equivalent of $564 million in an escrow account to comply with an order from India's market regulator.
It comes after the Securities and Exchange Board of India temporarily banned the trading giant from accessing the local market over allegations of index manipulation.
The deposit enables Jane Street to resume trading in India, but sources say the firm does not intend to return to trading in local equity options.
While Jane Street has not commented on the latest development, it has previously stated that it strongly rejects the premise and substance of the regulators order, calling it fundamentally mistaken about its trades.
Now, here in the UK, hiring by businesses is down by the most in nearly two years, according to data from the consultancy KPMG and the Recruitment and Employment Confederation.
The numbers come as employers show signs of dialing back hiring for jobs likely to be affected by artificial intelligence.
Bloomberg's Tio Adabio has more.
Online job postings in the UK have dropped 31% in the three months to May compared to 2022.
According to McKenzie analysis, the decline is being felt most in sectors with the potential to be significantly altered by AI, including areas such as tech and finance.
Data shows job postings for these sorts of roles dropped almost twice as much as others.
The trend presents another drag on a job market already contending with tax increases and stalling economic growth.
In London, Tiwa Adabio, Bloomberg Radio.
Britain has announced a date for the state visit from US President Donald Trump.
The country will host the American leader from the 17th of September after Prime Minister Kier Starmer invited Trump for a rare second visit.
Bloomberg's James Wilco has more.
Flashery can get you a long way.
In Britain's case, flattery seems to have helped K star secure a 20 percentage point lower tariff rate than that of the EU, which would be a major coup if it holds.
And global leaders admit to taking notes from this moment.
Can I present a letter from McCain to Thank you very much.
Oh, that's well that is really nice.
A very special letter.
I think the last state visit was a tremendous success.
It was uh His Majesty the king wants to make this even better.
Uh than that.
So this is this is truly historic an unprecedented second visit if he wants to.
So can Stan perform a second flourish and lever the UK's pageantry industry into real gains on trade and security from the US leader in London.
James Wilco, Bloomberg Radio.
President Donald Trump says that the US will send more Patriot air defense batteries to Ukraine as long as Europe pays.
The move is a change of heart for the US leader, who had argued that sending more arms would delay any peace deal.
Ukraine had been receiving US weapons, but only with money remaining from Joe Biden's time in office.
President Donald Trump says that he won't be footing the bill for the new deliveries.
I haven't agreed on the number yet, but they're going to have some because they do need protection.
But the European Union is paying for it.
We're not paying anything for it, but we will send it and it'll be business for us and we will send them patriots which they desperately need.
The president added that he is very disappointed with Russian President Vladimir Putin.
NATO chief Mark Russia is scheduled to meet with Trump later today as Axios reports that Trump will announce a new plan for Ukraine that also includes offensive weapons.
And in sports news, Yanek has captured his first Wimbledon title after defeating the defending champion Carlos Alcarz in four sets.
Speaking after the match, the Italian world number one acknowledged the challenges he's faced this year.
I'm very emotional.
No, even if I don't cry, but it feels uh feels emotional because only me and and the people who are close to me know exactly what we have been through on and off the court.
And it has been everything except easy.
Alex Center, who also served a three-month doping ban earlier in the year, speaking there.
Elsewhere, Chelsea claims the Football Club World Cup title, beating Paris San 3-nil in the final.
The London side were presented with the trophy by US President Donald Trump at the Metife Stadium in New Jersey.
Those are our top stories for you this morning.
Let's have a look at markets where stock futures are tumbling right now for Europe.
Down by half of 1% for the US stocks 50 futures.
Real concerns around President Donald Trump's tariff threat of 30% against Europe.
S&P 500 even futures also announcing some declines down 4/10en this morning.
Looking at the euro marginally lower against the dollar, down about a tenth of 1% for the euro 11675.
The Mexican peso is also down 210 against the dollar because it's another country uh in the sights of President Donald Trump uh with tariffs.
Asian equities are mixed.
You got the topics up.
The Cosby also seeing some gains uh but we've had some declines for example for the Taiwanese stock market.
Looking at Treasury yields hovering around 441.
The only other really big notable move again is in Bitcoin $121,000.
So it's breaking has broken through another record high for Bitcoin.
Those are the markets.
Stephen, in a moment we'll bring you the latest on the US EU trade moves.
Plus why Sweden's fighter jet industry could be poised for takeoff.
But another story we've been reading this morning from our opinion columnist Howard Chaywan who has been writing about getting healthy again while a little bit older at 66.
I decided to get healthy again as the essay that he's written for Bloomberg's weekend edition.
Um with some interesting I mean we've we like to feature how's writing a lot because he writes beautifully and in a very sort of relatable way about some of the kind of challenges he's had like taking up running uh in his 60s again.
He he gave it up earlier because of an injury as well.
And he's kind of talking about the the challenges of trying to be as active as possible.
Yes.
While also not compromising entirely on the things that he enjoys in life like eating out.
Yeah.
Absolutely.
He's a Boniv is he just is uh such a great writer.
Also that he often goes back to you know ancient texts which I just love.
You know he brings up lots of kind of Roman writers and he's got all sorts of interesting quotes that he um includes and kind of philosophical thinking.
It was based on science because he was looking at this recent scientific study that uh anybody who might be a little bit older um had probably spotted which is that apparently we age at certain points.
It doesn't sort of happen gradually but at around the age of 44 and around the age of 60 you can kind of age quite rapidly.
So he was trying to reverse that time and just like that effect you know and just like that you're feeling much older than perhaps you were last week or the week before.
There's great advice in there though from Howard too and essentially I mean a lot of it just comes down to don't give up and doing a little is better than doing nothing at all.
Um and you we'll put a link to the piece in our show notes.
It's a great read this morning.
Now let's bring you more on our top story.
So the EU is preparing to step up contacts with the likes of Canada and Japan after Donald Trump threatened to impose tariffs of 30% on its exports.
EU trade ministers are meeting in Brussels today to discuss the latest.
Our Brussels bureau chief Suzanne Lynch is joining us now for more.
Suzanne, good morning.
What do we know about the latest steps that the EU is planning?
Is this about trying to form alliances against the US?
Well, we reported late last night that the EU is preparing to step up engagement with other countries that are hit by the Donald Trump tariffs.
Um mainly it seems after this week of um and Donald Trump digging down on his trade rhetoric, sending those letters to various trading partners and then at the weekend announcing or threatening the European Union and Mexico with with new tariffs.
Um so we know that there is plan out to coordinate um a lot better on this.
Um but at the same time we've got the EU at the other hand signaling quite strongly by Ursula Vanderion on Sunday that they don't want to escalate at the moment um and that they're holding back implementing any more counter measures until they try and get some kind of a deal before this new August 1st deadline.
Suzan, talk us to us about the strategy that the EU is taking here because the decision not to retaliate is a choice.
Does it indicate that they are hopeful that c progress can be made between now and the 1st of August?
Well, it's um interesting timing because today, as you mentioned, EU trade ministers are meeting here in Brussels.
But today is also the deadline by which a suspended tariffs on steel and aluminum expire.
So the EU has a choice today as it happens whether to extend that suspension or to enact that suspension again and those tariffs again.
So we've heard very strongly from Vander Lion that at the moment today the EU won't do that that it will allow that uh suspension to continue.
So it it did have that option if you like and and they have chosen not to do that.
Um now what is interesting is that we you know we're hearing that for example from President Emmanuel Macron if you look at the language he used on Saturday when he responded to this kind of shock move by Trump he talked about the fact that the commission have to protect European interests.
He talked about preparing series of counter measures um including this trade tool called the anti-coercion instrument that could you know allow the EU to hit back even stronger.
He mentioned those things.
Now the EU hasn't gone there yet.
Um, as I say, it is at this moment deciding not to go any further.
But it will be interesting to see, you know, if there is some push back now today when EU trade ministers meeting that some countries perhaps believe, look, the EU needs to be stronger on this because, you know, as we've discussed before, the EU does have these other measures it can take.
It has other sanctions that it can h implement h if it chooses to do so.
Okay.
Well, let's watch that closely.
Suzanne, thank you so much for being with us this morning.
That is Bloomberg's Brussels Bureau Chief Suzanne Lynch.
The move to ramp up defense spending in Europe is presenting an opportunity for the Griffin jet made by Sweden's SAB.
The company hasn't secured an export order since 2014, but that might be about to change.
Our reporter Christopher Youngstat joins us now for more from Stockholm.
Christopher, good morning.
Is this the moment then for the Griffin fighter jet?
It sure does look like it's a a moment definitely.
As you mentioned, it's been over a decade since Saab won a major export order for its its grip and jets.
But in the past year, both Thailand and Colombia have decided that they do want to place orders.
And these are now being negotiated with Saab targeting deals being finalized this year.
And then next in line could be orders from Peru and the Philippines uh with Brazil potentially also boosting its existing contract for 36 jets by 25%.
And as as Saab CEO Michael Johansson said in his typical understated fashion, it's been a while since the company was in such an intensive period on the gapen front.
Well, Loheed Martin's F-35 fighter jets of course have dominated order books in Europe, but here two countries sort of looking for alternatives, right?
Yeah.
13 European countries are are current F-35 customers and that's including Sweden's neighbors Norway, Denmark and and Finland.
While Saab in its turn has just leased Gripen jets to the Czech Republic and Hungary.
The fact that Sweden hasn't been a NATO member has historically been one of their competitors main arguments for not buying the Gripen.
But with Sweden now a member, that's of course gone from their playbooks.
What's potentially an even bigger change, however, is the foreign policy shift of the Trump administration.
Uh pulling back support, as we all know, for Ukraine and raising doubts about US commitment to Europe's defense, uh which is quite frankly uncharted territory for European leaders.
So what's the hope then in terms of new orders for the Grip and Jet and for SAB that makes it?
Well, Saab executives have long emphasized that the procurement of a fighter jet is as much a political process as it is a purely technical one.
uh buying


Weapons and military gear from the US has long been viewed as a foolproof method to reach guaranteed friendship and support. But that is now, of course, no longer the case. Uh, with some security analysts believing that trust in the US will never go back to pre-Donald Trump levels. Consequently, uh, European countries are now trying to tow the line between lessening their dependence on the US and maintaining a healthy relationship as allies. Uh, some are starting to consider dual fleets, that is, mixing European-made fighters with their F-35s, and this to make up for a potentially lower level of US air support in the region. And some analysts expect European countries to spend a far smaller portion of its defense spending on US equipment over time as it supplies more of its own fighter aircraft.
